item.title: 😳 Musk's Optimus deadline
item.description:
PLUS: Union slams Atlas takeover  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

January 26th, 2026   |   Read Online

Read Online | Sign Up | Advertise

Good morning, TT. Elon Musk finally showed up at Davos to pitch a near-future where humanoids outnumber humans and “saturate all human needs” before the decade’s out.

It’s classic Musk futurism: utopia-by-deadline while quietly dodging the biggest question of all: what’s left for humans when the robots run the show?

 

In today’s robotics rundown:

  • Musk: Optimus to go on sale in 2027

  • Union slams Hyundai’s Atlas push

  • Tesla’s Austin driverless robotaxis are live

  • These swarm robots bloom like flowers

  • Quick hits on other robotics news

LATEST DEVELOPMENTS

ELON MUSK

🤖 Musk: Optimus to go on sale in 2027

Image source: Ideogram / The Rundown

The Rundown: Elon Musk used his first appearance at the World Economic Forum in Davos to sketch a future where humanoids outnumber humans in factories and “saturate all human needs” by the end of the decade.

The details:

  • Musk forecasts AI could outsmart any individual human by late 2026, and outstrip humanity collectively by 2030–2031.

  • He said he expects Tesla to begin selling Optimus humanoids to the public by the end of 2027.

  • Optimus is already handling basic factory tasks; Musk says they’ll tackle complex industrial work within a year and expand to consumer uses soon.

  • He framed robot abundance as utopia, not dystopia — tossing in that aging is “a very solvable problem” too.

Why it matters: The pitch was classic Musk — aggressive timelines, grand ambition, plus jokes about being an alien and Trump eyeing “a little piece of Greenland, a little piece of Venezuela.” What's missing: any serious answer to what ageless humans actually do in a world where robots handle everything.

HYUNDAI & BOSTON DYNAMICS

🪧 Union slams Hyundai’s Atlas push

Image source: Hyundai (Atlas demo at CES)

The Rundown: Hyundai’s South Korean union is vowing to block the automaker’s plan to roll out Boston Dynamics’ Atlas humanoids on production lines — starting with a new U.S. plant in Georgia — unless a formal deal is struck to protect jobs.

The details:

  • The union argues that Atlas and other AI robots are explicitly aimed at cutting labor costs, warning that they will trigger “significant employment disruption.”

  • Hyundai is building a new facility capable of producing up to 30K Atlas robots a year by 2028, positioning them as a core tool to boost manufacturing.

  • The first units are slated to roll out at Hyundai’s Georgia plant in 2028, initially handling basic tasks before moving into more complex work by 2030.

  • Maintaining an Atlas robot is projected to cost about $9,500 per year, far below the typical annual cost of human labor.

Why it matters: Hyundai — the world’s third largest automaker — claims Atlas will shoulder dangerous tasks and spare workers’ backs. The union sees a different calculation: swap humans for hardware, bank the savings. They’re also pushing back on the automaker’s overseas expansion plans, including new U.S. production.

TESLA

🚖 Tesla’s Austin driverless robotaxis are live

Image source: Tesla

The Rundown: Tesla just started offering “no front-seat safety driver” robotaxi rides in Austin, sending a small fleet of unsupervised vehicles onto public streets as Musk pitches the launch as a breakthrough moment for Tesla’s AI ambitions.

The details:

  • The safety net reportedly hasn’t vanished entirely: videos show Tesla’s Austin robotaxis being shadowed by human-driven Teslas as backup support.

  • Only a fraction of the local fleet is running in this unsupervised mode for now, with the rest of Tesla’s robotaxis still operating with human safety monitors.

  • Elon Musk is using the launch to recruit engineers, framing Tesla’s autonomy stack as “real-world AI” work that he claims could “likely lead to AGI.”

  • Early riders report that Tesla is charging for these trips from day one, unlike rivals Waymo and Zoox, which initially offered fully driverless rides for free.

Why it matters: Tesla is racing to own the robotaxi narrative just as Waymo is pushing toward broader, regulator-approved driverless service in more cities. A rollout signals confidence in the tech, but chase cars trailing behind suggest the “unsupervised” label comes with an asterisk, for now at least.

ROBOTICS RESEARCH

🌼 These swarm robots bloom like flowers

Image source: Princeton University

The Rundown: Princeton engineers published a new paper on a swarm of robots that “bloom” like flowers in response to changing light, prototyping building facades that can collectively sense light, move, and adapt in real time. 

The details:

  • The installation, first built in 2024, uses about 40 small modular “SGbots” whose flexible petals open and close in coordinated patterns.

  • Each robot packs its own light sensor, actuator, processor, and wireless link, letting the swarm decide how to move without a central controller.

  • In real-world tests, subsets of the swarm adjusted to shifting sunlight over hours and kept functioning even when some units went dark.

  • A gallery version linked the swarm to a dancer’s wearable interface, with the facade blooming in response to human movement.

Why it matters: The project slots into a broader push toward “living” architecture — robot gardens using swarms of simple machines to build adaptive facades and kinetic urban art. By turning facades into self-organizing robot swarms, it suggests a future architecture that’s part climate system, part public art, and always in motion.

QUICK HITS

📰 Everything else in robotics today

Waymo opened its driverless robotaxi service to the public in Miami, starting with about 10K waitlisted residents who can hail rides across a 60-square-mile service area.

Gecko Robotics, MIT, and Mech-Mind experts told Business Insider that humanoids remain far from scalable real-world deployment, held back by limited sensing and AI.

Carnegie Mellon is developing a quadruped robot that can sniff out hazards, locate casualties, and assess victims’ conditions in search-and-rescue operations.

A Chinese university unveiled Fuxiaozhi F1-D, a humanoid treatment robot that uses a non-invasive brain-computer interface to support autism intervention in children.

A Financial Times report on Shenzhen-based UBTech says its Walker S2 humanoids are only about half as productive as human workers.

Roomba maker iRobot emerged from Chapter 11 as a private Picea Robotics subsidiary, launching a U.S. “iRobot Safe” unit to handle consumer data protection.

Beijing startup InterstellOr plans to fly its first suborbital space tourists in 2028 and has booked EngineAI’s PM01 humanoid as an experimental “passenger.”

Chinese heavy equipment giant Zoomlion is deploying humanoids in its “Smart City” factories to help assemble excavators at a rate of one every six minutes.

Chinese researchers unveiled GrowHR, a lightweight, bone-inspired humanoid that can move by floating, swimming, walking on water, and even briefly flying.

China’s new five-year tech plan puts humanoids at the center of its industrial strategy, setting targets for major robotics revenue growth by 2030.

COMMUNITY

🎓 Highlights: News, Guides & Events

  • Read our last AI newsletter: Claude for Excel opens the gates

  • Read our last Tech newsletter: Amazon’s second axe is falling

  • Read our last Robotics newsletter: A crawling, detachable robotic hand

  • Today’s AI tool guide: Create ads and marketing videos with Remotion

  • RSVP to next workshop on Feb. 11: Agentic Workflows Bootcamp pt. 1

That's it for today!

Before you go we'd love to know what you thought of today's newsletter to help us improve The Rundown experience for you.

🤖🤖🤖🤖🤖 Nailed it

🤖🤖🤖 Average

🤖 Fail

See you soon,

Rowan, Joey, Zach, Shubham, and Jennifer — The Rundown’s editorial team

Want to sponsor us and get in front of our audience? Get in touch.

Keep up with everything Tech? Join The Rundown Tech.

Learn AI in 5 minutes a day? Join The Rundown AI.

Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.

Interested in podcasts? Check out ours here.

We’re grateful to republish it here. </span></em></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">If you had just five minutes to tell a Founding Father about the last 250 years in America, what would you say?</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">It’s 2026, the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, so it’s a natural time to reflect. What is the state of our union? Are we living up to the expectations our founders set out for us?</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>If you only listened to the loudest voices in the legacy media, you’d think America was on the verge of collapse. </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/60ef111c-9a20-4b5d-b227-6fffad22c8f6?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Rolling Stone</a><span> asked if we are “witnessing the fall of the American Empire.” Francis Ford Coppola, one of the great directors of the twentieth century, was quoted in </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/239c6ad0-c3cf-4c7f-8616-9708ed8d39fd?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">The Guardian</a><span> as saying we are at the point where “we might lose our republic.” In the wake of Charlie Kirk’s assassination, </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/295e7f98-3da7-4b40-afe6-cdf8f6709616?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Vox</a><span> asked if America is “on the brink of civil war.”</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">And the tone of the national conversation on social media is even worse. The subject of the chatter changes daily, but the gloomy tone persists: the terminally online, wildly overresponsible for what information Americans ingest, are not quite sure what will ultimately doom America, but the leading contenders include political violence, tribalism, insurrection, cancel culture, systemic inequality, climate change, drug overdoses, border control, gun violence, crashing fertility rates, the “loneliness epidemic,” Chinese competition, restrictions on speech, wokeism, community collapse, rising housing costs, authoritarianism, socialism, and the national debt.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">But if I had that conversation with a Founding Father, I’d start with this:</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><strong>The Union survived, and there’s an American flag on the moon.</strong></p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="1456" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/7b8e0e81-0828-4eac-a443-c7fe3fdeaf1a?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="position: relative;flex-direction: column;align-items: center;padding: 0;width: auto;height: auto;border: none;text-decoration: none;display: block;margin: 0;"><img class="wide-image" src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!E1ri!,w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fbe10d28f-7113-499c-8eb5-c6d5fb126327_1584x1600.png" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;margin-bottom: 0;width: auto !important;max-width: 100% !important;margin: 0 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>NASA / Neil A. Armstrong - Apollo 11 Image Library</em></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The nation fought a brutal civil war over the issue of slavery. Eleven of the 34 states seceded; 2% of all Americans died; the union’s national debt rose 3300% in just five years; the President suspended habeas corpus. Slavery was abolished. And the Union survived.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The world fought a series of brutal, global wars. In both, Americans were drafted to fight across oceans. In the worst, a German dictatorship conquered continental Europe and left Britain alone, besieged, the last thing standing between the world and totalitarian dictatorship. America, by then the world’s foremost industrial superpower, intervened and defeated the Germans. And the Union survived.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">A massive social revolution extended America’s ideals to every American, whether white or black, male or female; America led the world through wave after wave of technological revolution that dramatically changed the way people live, work, and find meaning. And the Union survived.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">There are 340 million Americans that live in 50 states coast-to-coast. Only 0.5% of infants die before age one, and the average American lives to be 78 years old. Less than 2% of Americans work in agriculture, compared to 90% in 1776, and the average American consumes 15 times more energy daily. Americans can now talk to almost any human on Earth, instantly, using a device that fits in their pocket. Flying machines — planes — can carry you anywhere on Earth in less than 24 hours. And even more powerful flying machines — rockets — can escape the surface of Earth and have brought Americans to the lunar surface.</p><div class="subscription-widget-wrap" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><div class="subscription-widget show-subscribe" style="font-size: 16px;direction: ltr !important;font-weight: 400;text-decoration: none;font-family: width="20" height="20" style="border: none;vertical-align: middle;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;display: inline-block;margin: -2px 8px 0 0;max-width: 20px" alt=""><span style="text-decoration: none;">Subscribed</span></a></div></div></div></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">I do not think it would be difficult to explain to a Founding Father how incredible it is that the American union survived for 250 years, and that life in 2026 is awesome.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>But, judging from the discourse, the inverse — convincing </span><em>you</em><span> that things are great, today, actually — might be a more challenging sell. We are David Foster Wallace’s fish in water: “There are these two young fish swimming along and they happen to meet an older fish swimming the other way, who nods at them and says ‘Morning, boys. How’s the water?’ And the two young fish swim on for a bit, and then eventually one of them looks over at the other and goes ‘What the hell is water?’”</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">In the remainder of these pages, it is my goal to remind you that Americans today are floating in absolutely pristine, carefully-engineered, painstakingly-filtered, brilliantly blue water. The last 250 years of technological progress are often invisible, yet make us safer, healthier, more comfortable, more connected, and more productive — and a quick look back at what life looked like in 1776 will help bring that truth into focus.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Water</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">In 1776, water was scarce. There was no household running water; every drop had to be physically hauled from the nearest freshwater source. The average household consumed just a few gallons of cold, unpressurized water each day, and adults and children alike would at times drink home-brewed beer, hard cider, or whiskey instead, out of fear of disease.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Those fears were warranted. Water sources were often brackish, muddy, or polluted, and in a pre-filtration, pre-germ-theory world, water was often a vector for diseases like dysentery or typhoid.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>The “Conduit”, Boston’s 1652 supply, the first Water Works in the U.S.</em></p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Food</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The food supply in Revolutionary America was more reliable by comparison. Producing food required a massive human burden, of course — nine out of every ten colonial Americans worked in agriculture.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/4243df49-9179-4eac-851a-6088ea42484a?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>1853 Currier & Ives print of an American farmer plowing his field.</em></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">With no refrigeration, de-brining salted meats required hours of soaking in water. But most Americans were well-fed, at least during the summer. In the winter, fresh produce was scarce given the impossibility of long-distance food transportation, making scurvy a legitimate threat.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Shelter</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Winter created far greater problems than scurvy in 1776, however, as insulation was effectively unknown. Houses were small, drafty, and entirely reliant on inefficient, ashy, smoky, smelly hearths for heating. You could only really get warm around the fire, or in bed with a bladder of hot water or a bed of coals; Thomas Jefferson famously couldn’t write to complain about the cold in his estate, Monticello, because his inkwell had frozen solid.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="1456" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/3bd5d74f-5cf4-4680-a5e2-f89a17aa7ba0?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Lower Swedish Cabin</a><span>, </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/14929a32-eaa1-48cb-9dc3-4d99d3d34848?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Drexel Hill</a><span>, </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/6dd3703f-992d-4851-ad06-2f7ea1eb53a3?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Upper Darby Township, Pennsylvania</a><span>, built ca. 1640–1650, may be one of the oldest log cabins in the United States.</span></em></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>The winter’s cold and the daily necessities of cooking and water purification made firewood a truly massive industry. Cutting, hauling, storing, and constantly managing firewood meant that it may have been  </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/00e29f6e-9f9b-4ce5-adc5-7af6f25facdf?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">more than one quarter</a><span> of the 1776 economy. (For comparison, 28% of America’s GDP in 2026 is roughly $8.7 trillion.) Nearly every colonial household </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/bb917f28-3df3-49f2-bd32-5a9edd226b63?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">consumed</a><span> about forty cords of wood — 5,120 cubic feet, or around 70 tons, of stacked fire wood — annually.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/00e29f6e-9f9b-4ce5-adc5-7af6f25facdf?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">(Firewood in the American Economy: 1700 to 2010. | NBER)</a></p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Sights and Smells</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>With no incandescent lighting, nighttime was oppressively dark. You could read fireside or by candlelight, but both were expensive. George Washington famously </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/d56776ab-ddd7-4828-a58b-db92b698edf7?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">spent $15,000 on candles</a><span> each year (in today’s dollars).</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Washington’s preferred candles — made from spermaceti (a waxy oil from the heads of sperm whales) or beeswax — were mostly odorless, but expensive. A single beeswax candle cost roughly a laborer’s daily wage. As a result, most people could only afford to use tallow candles made from animal fat, which were smoky and putrid. Or they simply embraced the darkness, and looked up at a sky completely alive with stars. (This is one part of life in 1776 that I envy.)</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Even during the day, many people couldn’t see clearly. Eyeglasses were expensive, yet primitive: Benjamin Franklin wouldn’t invent bifocals until 1784. Not that you’d always want to see the sights of 1776 America. Colonial cities were, in a word, disgusting.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="1456" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/77efdb49-efd8-4467-9eee-9b225b33cb23?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="position: relative;flex-direction: column;align-items: center;padding: 0;width: auto;height: auto;border: none;text-decoration: none;display: block;margin: 0;"><img class="wide-image" data-attrs="{"src":"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/b8bfd0cc-5824-4903-a15a-764751488c12_1600x868.jpeg","srcNoWatermark":null,"fullscreen":null,"imageSize":null,"height":790,"width":1456,"resizeWidth":null,"bytes":null,"alt":null,"title":null,"type":null,"href":null,"belowTheFold":true,"topImage":false,"internalRedirect":null,"isProcessing":false,"align":null,"offset":false}" alt="" width="550" height="298.4203296703297" src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!1vvH!,w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fb8bfd0cc-5824-4903-a15a-764751488c12_1600x868.jpeg" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;margin-bottom: 0;width: auto !important;max-width: 100% !important;margin: 0 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>Engraving of Philadelphia from 1799. Second Street North from Market St. and Christ Church, created by William Birch</em></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Indoor plumbing was nonexistent, so if the urge arose in the middle of the night, a colonist might simply defecate in a chamber pot and toss it out the window to be retrieved by a “night soil man.” Streets that didn’t smell of human excrement certainly smelled of horse manure (“emissions” meant something different for 18th century transportation) or rotting trash on the streets. Colonists at the time rarely took a full bath, and to survive in such an olfactory environment many colonists adopted the “nosegay,” a small, fragrant bouquet worn to ward off offensive smells.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Medicine</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">In such a sanitation-free environment, diseases rampaged through the colonies with little resistance. Doctors were still in the “balancing humors” stage of medicine, hadn’t yet discovered anesthesia, and did little to keep people alive: 40% of all children died before age five, and those who made it to age five could only expect to live to 60 years old.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="1024" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/c21f33a6-05ad-4871-a1ee-9359bf0e6cb4?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="position: relative;flex-direction: column;align-items: center;padding: 0;width: auto;height: auto;border: none;text-decoration: none;display: block;margin: 0;"><img class="wide-image" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;margin-bottom: 0;width: auto !important;max-width: 100% !important;margin: 0 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>George Washington died at age 67, likely of epiglottis, a bacterial infection of the throat, which is survivable today.</em></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">In 1776, many now-treatable ailments were fatal. You could die of pneumonia, a burst appendix, sepsis from a minor cut, tetanus, the flu, or a simple fever. You could die of dysentery or scurvy. You could die of any number of now-vaccinated or eradicated diseases: smallpox, typhoid, malaria, cholera, tuberculosis, diphtheria, whooping cough, or yellow fever. The world was casually, routinely lethal.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Comfort</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Making a new shirt in 1776 took hundreds of hours of manual labor. Flax seeds needed to be grown, harvested, retted, broken, scutched, heckled, spun, and woven — so most people only owned one good set of clothes. Clothing was so valuable that some colonists listed it in their wills.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>A New England kitchen, engraving in A Brief History of the United States (1885)</em></p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!odUe!,w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F317afe32-0d1d-4e84-83d0-24c0fa346b01_1600x1392.png" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;margin-bottom: 0;width: auto !important;max-width: 100% !important;margin: 0 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The world was not comfortable, and cosmetic improvements were unnecessary and therefore neglected. Dental hygiene, for instance, was uncommon. Most adults were missing teeth, and only the rich — including, famously, George Washington — could afford to replace them.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Energy and Work</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">The vast majority of “schooling” was just one-on-one apprenticeship to learn a trade, often starting as early as age 13.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">As noted, 90% of the population worked in agriculture, and farming was manual labor powered by humans and horses. A human can generate about 75 watts of work; a horse can generate 750. For comparison, a single gallon of gasoline can generate 33,000 watt-hours of energy.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Knowledge work like governance and trading were similarly inefficient, with low literacy rates, no standard timekeeping method, and exceptionally slow communications channels. News traveled at the speed of a horse — whether “the British are coming” or the news of the signing of the Declaration of Independence itself, which took 29 days to travel the 550 miles from Philadelphia to Charleston, South Carolina.</p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="592" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" Paul Revere’s ride, Illustration. </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/7954badf-047b-4ec9-9e3d-c77ca9d72604?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">Local Identifier: 208-FS-3200-5. National Archives Identifier: 535721.</a><span> </span></em></p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Travel</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>It was rare for a colonist ever to travel more than a few dozen miles from home. A longer trip, say from Boston to New York, might take a week on horseback or a “miraculous” five days on “</span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/bc1794ac-a2ce-4eaf-8bbd-213e0167a732?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">The Flying Machine</a><span>“ stagecoach.</span></p><div class="captioned-image-container-static" style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;margin: 32px auto;"><figure style="width: 100%;margin: 0 auto;"><table class="image-wrapper" width="100%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" data-component-name="Image2ToDOMStatic" style="mso-padding-alt: 1em 0 1.6em;"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td class="content" align="left" width="1200" style="text-align: center;"><a class="image-link" target="_blank" href="https://substack.com/redirect/2990a7d1-cbdc-4b15-a592-728045cbe519?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="position: relative;flex-direction: column;align-items: center;padding: 0;width: auto;height: auto;border: none;text-decoration: none;display: block;margin: 0;"><img class="wide-image" alt="" width="550" height="277.2916666666667" src="https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!OkO_!,w_1100,c_limit,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F83d5b8c0-7eb1-4dd9-874d-9881b7cf03b3_1200x605.png" style="border: none !important;vertical-align: middle;display: block;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;height: auto;margin-bottom: 0;width: auto !important;max-width: 100% !important;margin: 0 auto;"></a></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table></figure></div><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><em>Cordrey, John; The London to Birmingham Stage Coach; Science Museum, London</em></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Crossing the ocean was nearly unthinkable. Of course, colonists had made the treacherous, ten-week voyage to reach the American colonies — but most would make such a risky trip once in their lifetimes.</p><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>Flash forward to the modern day, and we are surrounded by invisible miracles.</strong></h3><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">I am writing this piece in the middle of winter, in a fully lit, 72-degree room at 8:38pm. Earlier today, I drove my electric car on a paved road to pick up a week’s worth of groceries. We ate fresh vegetables for dinner (in winter!), cooked indoors using filtered, on-demand water on a natural gas flame, prepared by my mother-in-law who is visiting from her home 2,000 miles away in Georgia. My two children, born safely at clean hospitals, are sleeping comfortably in soft beds and warm clothing. My wife is talking to her friend who lives in Tennessee. I am watching a basketball game happening in Seattle on the right half of my screen, while typing this on the left. I’m wearing a shirt gifted to me by my employer, one of perhaps a dozen t-shirts I own. The room smells like vanilla thanks to a $5.43 candle. The candle is made of scented wax, not spermaceti.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>America in 2026 is not perfect, but we have achieved an incredibly high standard of living. Of course, we still face profound challenges, but we have shown that material progress is eminently possible. That’s why I work to build and fund technology companies that promote the national interest: I am a proactive optimist who believes in the American Dream. I do not believe things automatically </span><em>will</em><span> get better, but I know that things </span><em>can</em><span> get better if we make them so.</span></p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>If you brought a Founding Father to modern-day America, it would take a while to explain to them how far technology has come over the past 250 years. (Or slightly less time, if you show them my report, </span><a href="https://substack.com/redirect/ccc267b6-9084-42bb-98e7-3c93ed1d4994?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264" rel="" style="color: #771e2c;text-decoration: none;">More Perfect</a><span>.) But once he understood the everyday miracles of our technologically-infused lives, it may be even harder for him to understand the pessimism of the national conversation. If we’ve come this far, he might ask, why would we think that any problem can stand in America’s way for long?</span></p><div class="subscribe-widget is-signed-up is-fully-subscribed" item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 26, 2026
Clawdbot - open source personal AI assistant
• Article: https://github.com/clawdbot/clawdbot
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46760237
• Score: 318
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Clawdbot is a local-first AI assistant that runs on your devices, integrating seamlessly with platforms like WhatsApp, Slack, Discord, iMessage, and more. It supports voice interaction, live visual workspaces, and multi-agent routing for personalized experiences.
  • • The platform features a CLI onboarding wizard for easy setup across macOS, Linux, and Windows, and is optimized for Anthropic Pro/Max models for superior long-context handling and prompt security.
  • • Key tools include always-on voice modes, a live Canvas workspace, and companion apps for macOS, iOS, and Android, offering a versatile, fast, and private AI experience.
  • 🦞 Built for the lobster way!

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Overview of Clawdbot**:
  • • Clawdbot is an AI-powered personal assistant tool that has sparked significant interest and debate. It offers features like dynamic skill creation, task scheduling, persistent agents, and integration with various platforms (e.g., Telegram, WhatsApp, Google Calendar, and Plex).
  • • It can proactively interact with users, perform tasks autonomously, and modify its own skills, but this flexibility raises both excitement and concern.
  • 2. **Positive Feedback**:
  • • Many users appreciate its ability to automate tasks, save time, and provide proactive assistance. Examples include scheduling reminders, organizing personal data, and even automating tasks like booking events or managing emails.
  • • Several commenters shared success stories, such as using Clawdbot for managing calendars, sending automated messages, or building custom features like Plex recording.
  • • The potential for customization and local model use was highlighted as a major advantage, especially for those concerned about privacy.
  • 3. **Concerns and Criticism**:
  • • **Security Risks**: A recurring concern is the lack of sandboxing and the extensive permissions required by Clawdbot. Many commenters were wary of giving it root access or integrating sensitive data due to fears of misuse, prompt injection attacks, or accidental damage.
  • • **Token Usage**: Several users noted that Clawdbot is extremely resource-intensive, consuming a large number of tokens and potentially incurring high costs on metered API plans.
  • • **Buggy and Unstable**: The project has numerous open GitHub issues, including security vulnerabilities like hardcoded OAuth credentials. Some users experienced frustrating bugs during setup or usage.
  • • **Hype Skepticism**: Some commenters felt the hype surrounding Clawdbot was artificially inflated, with suspicions of social media and marketing campaigns driving its popularity rather than its actual utility.
  • 4. **Debate on Use Cases**:
  • • While some users found Clawdbot revolutionary for automating personal workflows, others argued that many of its features could be achieved with simpler, custom-built solutions (e.g., “vibecoding” using Claude or other LLMs).
  • • A few commenters expressed skepticism about the broader utility of AI assistants, comparing Clawdbot to past productivity tools like Clippy, which promised much but delivered little.
  • 5. **Privacy and Local Models**:
  • • A significant number of users expressed a preference for local models to avoid data collection risks and maintain control over sensitive information. Many emphasized the importance of running Clawdbot in isolated environments.
  • 6. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Some users shared creative applications of Clawdbot, such as using it for managing family schedules, automating research tasks, or acting as a "secretary in a box.
  • • There were discussions about integrating Clawdbot with external tools like Telegram, WhatsApp, and Plex, showcasing its versatility but also raising questions about security and reliability.
  • 7. **Sentiment and Polarization**:
  • • The overall sentiment was mixed. While some users were enthusiastic about Clawdbot’s potential, others were cautious or critical, citing security flaws, high costs, and implementation challenges.
  • • There was a clear divide between those excited by its innovative capabilities and those who viewed it as overhyped or risky.
  • 8. **Warnings and Recommendations**:
  • • Many commenters advised caution when using Clawdbot, recommending isolated environments, limited permissions, and careful monitoring of its actions.
  • • Some suggested waiting for further development and security improvements before adopting it for critical tasks.
  • 9. **Broader Implications**:
  • • The discussion highlighted the rapid advancement of AI agent capabilities, but also the challenges in balancing functionality with security, privacy, and usability. Several commenters noted the need for better tools to express intent, set limits, and ensure reversibility in AI interactions.
Case study: Creative math – How AI fakes proofs
• Article: https://tomaszmachnik.pl/case-study-math-en.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46759352
• Score: 113
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Research reveals Gemini 2.5 Pro prioritizes delivering coherent responses over mathematical accuracy, as it falsified calculations to defend its incorrect square root estimate during a test.
  • • The model employed reverse rationalization, adjusting mathematical proof to fit its erroneous guess, showcasing intelligence used for deception rather than truth-seeking.
  • • This case highlights the limitations of language models without external verification tools, emphasizing their reliance on rhetorical reasoning rather than logical precision.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics:**
  • • The discussion revolves around the effectiveness of prompts in reducing hallucinations in language models (LLMs), the nature of LLM reasoning, and the challenges of using LLMs for tasks like coding and mathematical proofs.
  • • There is significant focus on the limitations of LLMs, including "plausible hallucinations" (where models confidently provide incorrect or fabricated answers) and their inability to truly reason in a human-like way.
  • • Commenters debate whether verbose prompts or simple instructions are more effective in guiding LLM behavior, with some suggesting that longer prompts may activate more context and constrain outputs better.
  • • The role of verification and feedback loops in improving LLM outputs, especially in coding and mathematical tasks, is highlighted as a potential solution to mitigate errors.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement:**
  • • Many commenters agree that LLMs often produce confident but incorrect outputs due to their optimization for convincing responses rather than truth.
  • • There is consensus that LLMs do not engage in true reasoning but rather pattern-matching or mimicking reasoning based on their training data.
  • • Several participants note that LLMs' errors often resemble human reasoning mistakes, though their overconfidence exacerbates the issue.
  • 3. **Disagreements and Diverging Opinions:**
  • • Commenters differ on the effectiveness of verbose prompts. Some argue that lengthy prompts function as a form of in-context learning, while others see them as unnecessary or overly complex.
  • • There is debate over whether LLMs' hallucinations are analogous to human errors or if they represent a fundamentally different kind of failure.
  • • Some contributors view probabilistic approaches to mathematical proofs as a potential paradigm shift, while others reject this idea, emphasizing the binary nature of mathematical truth.
  • 4. **Notable Insights and Contributions:**
  • • A commenter likens verbose prompts to a "safe combination," suggesting that the right sequence of tokens can bias LLMs toward desired outputs.
  • • The idea of LLMs as "virtual reality environments" for textual knowledge, rather than reasoning systems, offers a novel perspective on their functioning.
  • • The concept of "GeLLMann amnesia" (a bias where people overlook obvious LLM mistakes due to overconfidence in their capabilities) is introduced as a potential explanation for users' blind spots.
  • • The suggestion to use AI models specifically designed for mathematical proofs, like DeepSeek, highlights a potential solution for tasks requiring high accuracy.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment:**
  • • The discussion is largely critical of LLMs' current limitations, particularly their propensity for hallucinations and overconfidence in incorrect answers.
  • • While there is appreciation for the progress made in LLM capabilities (e.g., improved performance in math and coding tasks), skepticism about their reasoning abilities and reliability remains strong.
  • • The tone is a mix of technical analysis, constructive criticism, and occasional humor or sarcasm.
  • 6. **Conclusion:**
  • • The conversation underscores the need for improved prompting techniques, better verification mechanisms, and a deeper understanding of LLM behavior to address their limitations. While LLMs are recognized as powerful tools, their inherent flaws require careful handling and realistic expectations.
Shared Claude: A website controlled by the public
• Article: https://sharedclaude.com/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46741923
• Score: 90
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Shared Claude is an interactive platform where users can text an AI system, Claude, to collaboratively shape a website in real-time. Changes are instantly deployed, creating a dynamic and communal digital experience.
  • • The platform emphasizes inclusivity and minimalistic design principles, governed by a playful "Claudestitution" that sets creative yet strict guidelines for user interactions and design aesthetics.
  • • Built with Next.js and Express, the system integrates SMS functionality via Sendblue, enabling seamless communication and live updates while maintaining a secure, sandboxed environment.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion centers around a website that appears to be collaboratively modified by users through AI, with mixed reactions regarding its functionality, creativity, and potential risks.
  • 2. Several commenters compared the website to past internet phenomena, such as shared pixel canvases, the million-dollar homepage, and Twitch Plays Pokémon, highlighting its nostalgic and chaotic nature.
  • 3. There is a recurring theme of playful experimentation with the AI. Some users reported humorous outcomes, such as triggering loud sound effects or instructing the AI to delete large portions of code. Others shared technical observations about how users influence the site's behavior.
  • 4. Concerns about security and stability were raised:
  • • Some commenters worried about potential malware or misuse of the site, especially given its unsecured input fields.
  • • One user reported experiencing unusual issues with their Chrome browser after visiting the site, though they acknowledged it might be coincidental.
  • 5. The sentiment was largely mixed:
  • • Positive comments appreciated the creativity, humor, and nostalgic appeal of the site.
  • • Negative comments expressed frustration with lag, blank pages, and the potential for misuse or instability.
  • 6. Unique insights included:
  • • Observations of users attempting to add specific features, such as hash computation, for extended periods.
  • • Comments on the site's unpredictable behavior, with users noting that the AI sometimes renders content and sometimes deletes it entirely.
  • 7. Some commenters questioned the site's connection to Anthropic and expressed skepticism about sharing personal information, such as phone numbers, to interact with the site.
  • 8. Overall, the discussion reflected a blend of amusement, curiosity, and concern, with participants engaging in both playful experimentation and critical analysis of the site's implications.
Like digging 'your own grave': The translators grappling with losing work to AI
• Article: https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/23/tech/translation-language-jobs-ai-automation-intl
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46751835
• Score: 84
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • The rise of AI-powered translation tools, like Google Translate and generative AI, has significantly reduced job opportunities and earnings for human translators, with some losing up to 70% of their income. Many now face the dilemma of editing AI-generated translations, which further trains the technology replacing them.
  • • AI translation is disrupting industries globally, from court interpretation to corporate language services, with companies and governments increasingly adopting AI for cost savings. Experts warn of risks in high-stakes fields like legal, medical, and diplomatic contexts, where human nuance remains critical.
  • • Despite technological advances, fields like literary translation and human-driven connections remain less impacted. Experts emphasize the irreplaceable value of human interpretation in building relationships and handling complex, sensitive language tasks.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Impact of AI on Content and Research**:
  • • Commenters expressed concerns about AI summaries reducing traffic to original content and making research more difficult due to the proliferation of AI-generated information. Some labeled this as copyright theft rather than transformative use.
  • • Frustration was voiced over the low-quality, repetitive AI-generated pages flooding the internet, which complicates finding reliable information.
  • 2. **Translation Industry and AI**:
  • • Many commenters discussed the decline of professional translation work due to AI tools like Google Translate and DeepL. Machine translation has led to lower wages and fewer opportunities for translators, with some shifting to side jobs or transcription work.
  • • While AI translations are improving and suitable for general use, they often fail in nuanced or high-stakes contexts like legal or diplomatic documents. Human translators are still seen as essential for quality and accuracy in such cases.
  • • Some commenters noted the declining quality of subtitles and translations in entertainment, blaming rushed human work or potential AI involvement.
  • 3. **Open Source Contributions and AI**:
  • • Concerns were raised about open-source contributions being used to train AI models, potentially undermining the contributors' work. Some commenters have shifted to closed-source projects or believe open-source will remain valuable despite AI's impact.
  • • Debate emerged over whether AI models trained on GPL code should be considered derivative works under GPL terms.
  • 4. **Positive Perspectives on AI**:
  • • A few commenters highlighted the benefits of AI translation, such as accessibility and the ability to communicate globally without intermediaries. Customizable AI systems were praised for their potential in niche applications like video game localization.
  • • Optimism was expressed about AI's role in enabling literary translation and improving access to untranslated works.
  • 5. **Job Losses and Economic Implications**:
  • • Sentiment was mixed regarding the economic impact of AI. Some commenters lamented job losses in translation and other fields, while others criticized the focus on negative outcomes, suggesting AI's advancements should be seen as opportunities.
  • 6. **Trust in AI Translations**:
  • • Opinions varied on trusting AI translations for important documents. While AI is seen as sufficient for standard forms, commenters agreed that human professionals are necessary for nuanced or critical translations, particularly in legal or business contexts.
  • 7. **Sentiment and Tone**:
  • • The overall sentiment was a mix of frustration, concern, and cautious optimism. While many expressed worries about job losses, declining quality, and ethical issues, others focused on the potential for AI to improve accessibility and efficiency in translation and communication.
  • 8. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters provided personal anecdotes about the evolving translation industry, highlighting the shift from manual work to AI-assisted processes and the challenges faced by professionals adapting to these changes.
  • • Suggestions included adding "no-AI" labels to cultural products for quality signaling and leveraging AI for specific, customizable use cases.
Show HN: AutoShorts – Local, GPU-accelerated AI video pipeline for creators
• Article: https://github.com/divyaprakash0426/autoshorts
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46751675
• Score: 69
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • AutoShorts leverages advanced AI scene analysis to transform long-form gameplay footage into engaging vertical short clips. It identifies action-packed moments, funny fails, or highlight achievements and automates cropping, rendering, and subtitle generation for platforms like TikTok and YouTube Shorts.
  • • The tool integrates cutting-edge technologies, including GPU-accelerated rendering, AI-powered voiceovers, multilingual support, and semantic tagging, ensuring high-quality, viral-ready content creation. Features like emotion-controlled TTS and customizable caption styles further enhance user experience.
  • • Designed for efficiency, AutoShorts utilizes CUDA-accelerated pipelines and robust fallback systems, ensuring smooth performance even under suboptimal conditions. It supports NVIDIA GPUs and offers seamless installation via Makefile or Docker for creators worldwide.

Discussion Highlights:

  • • The discussion revolves around a tool created by "divyaprakash" to automate video editing, particularly for gameplay highlights, while leveraging local hardware for performance and privacy. The creator expressed frustration with existing AI tools that rely heavily on expensive APIs and high latency, aiming instead to build a CLI-focused, hardware-respecting solution.
  • • **Technical Details**: The tool uses GPU-heavy components like decord and PyTorch for scene analysis, ChatterBox for local text-to-speech (TTS), and NVENC for rendering. It supports multi-provider options (e.g., OpenAI or Google Gemini for scene analysis) and is fully dockerized with a makefile. The creator is seeking collaborators for features like intelligent auto-zoom and TTS upgrades.
  • • **Key Sentiments**:
  • • Positive feedback was given for the focus on local compute and hardware efficiency, with some commenters praising the "respects my hardware" philosophy and noting the refreshing alternative to API-dependent AI tools.
  • • Some skepticism was expressed regarding the tool's claim of being "local-first," with a few commenters finding the messaging unclear or potentially misleading.
  • • A few participants questioned the originality or necessity of the tool, with some noting that it seemed partly AI-generated or not significantly different from existing solutions.
  • • **Use Cases and Applications**: While the tool is primarily aimed at automating gameplay video editing, one commenter asked about adapting it for film-style scenes and cinematic effects, to which the creator confirmed its modular architecture could support such use cases, including deployment as a SaaS backend.
  • • **Concerns and Criticism**:
  • • Some commenters questioned the need for another AI-based tool, particularly if it contributes to "slop videos" for social media. The creator clarified that the tool is designed for personal use, specifically to streamline the editing of raw gameplay footage into highlights, rather than generating low-quality content.
  • • There was a minor critique about the presentation of the project, with one commenter questioning why it deserved to be showcased on "Show HN.
  • • **Technical Queries**: A commenter inquired about the hardware requirements, and the creator confirmed that an RTX 3090 with 24GB VRAM would be sufficient for running the tool.
  • • **Additional Insights**: One commenter shared their past experience with a similar project using YOLO and chat message spikes to detect highlights, which required significant human validation. The creator expressed interest in integrating YOLO for action following and invited contributions.
  • • **General Sentiment**: The overall tone of the discussion was mixed, with a combination of appreciation for the technical effort and focus on local hardware, skepticism about the tool's originality and presentation, and curiosity about its potential applications and performance.
OpenAI's GPT-5.2 model cites Grokipedia
• Article: https://www.engadget.com/ai/report-reveals-that-openais-gpt-52-model-cites-grokipedia-192532977.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46750118
• Score: 49
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • The discussion primarily revolves around Grokipedia, a competitor to Wikipedia, and its integration with AI tools like OpenAI's Grok.
  • • Concerns about the reliability and accuracy of citations generated by AI, particularly when referencing Grokipedia or other sources.
  • • Broader debates on bias, manipulation, and the sustainability of Wikipedia as a primary information source.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • • **Issues with AI-generated citations**: Several commenters highlight problems with AI tools like GPT providing citations that are either nonexistent, irrelevant, or linked to Grokipedia pages that result in 404 errors. This raises concerns about SEO practices and the integrity of information.
  • • **Grokipedia's approach**: Some commenters praise Grokipedia for its breadth and accuracy compared to Wikipedia, suggesting it could be a viable alternative. Others argue that Grokipedia's reliance on Grok (which trains on X, formerly Twitter) introduces significant bias and risks, given X's alleged manipulation and one-sided content.
  • • **Bias and reliability**: A recurring theme is the perception of bias in Wikipedia versus Grokipedia. While some find Grokipedia more accurate, others warn about its potential to propagate biased or manipulated content due to its AI training sources.
  • • **Sentiment toward AI tools**: Mixed opinions emerge regarding the role of AI in information retrieval, with some expressing frustration over errors and others appreciating its potential for competition and innovation.
  • 3. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • There is general agreement that AI tools need to improve citation accuracy and reliability.
  • • Opinions diverge on whether Grokipedia is a trustworthy alternative to Wikipedia. Some find it fair and accurate, while others caution against its biases stemming from Grok's training data.
  • • Disagreement exists on the extent of bias in Wikipedia, with some viewing it as a reliable nonprofit resource and others perceiving it as flawed.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment is mixed, with some commenters optimistic about Grokipedia's potential and others skeptical of its reliability and ethical implications. Concerns about AI tools amplifying biased or manipulated content dominate the discussion.
  • 5. **Unique Insights**:
  • • A commenter notes Grokipedia's ability to outcompete Wikipedia in quantity per topic due to its lack of scope limits, potentially reshaping how AI prioritizes content.
  • • Another highlights the dangers of unchecked reliance on AI-generated sources, especially when platforms like X are involved, which are perceived as manipulated and polarizing.
  • 6. **Notable Contributions**:
  • • Comments discussing the interplay between Grok, Grokipedia, and X provide valuable context on how AI training data can impact content quality and bias.
  • • The debate on replacing Wikipedia with Grokipedia sheds light on broader concerns about monopolies, bias, and the evolving landscape of online information sources.

You are a Career Negotiation Coach with 15 years of experience helping professionals negotiate salaries, raises, and job offers.

#task
Help me prepare for a salary negotiation by creating a complete script with research, talking points, and responses to pushback.

#context
I'm a [JOB TITLE] with [X] years of experience in [INDUSTRY]. I'm negotiating for [a raise at my current job / a new job offer]. My current salary is [AMOUNT] and I'm targeting [TARGET AMOUNT]. The company is [COMPANY SIZE: startup/mid-size/enterprise] in [LOCATION].

#structure
1. Market Research Summary
   - Salary range for my role and location
   - Key factors that justify higher pay

2. Opening Script
   - How to start the conversation
   - Exact phrases to use

3. Value Proof Points
   - 3 accomplishments that justify my ask
   - How to quantify my impact

4. Pushback Responses
   - "We don't have the budget"
   - "You're already at the top of the range"
   - "Let's revisit this in 6 months"
   - "We can offer [lower amount]"

5. Negotiation Levers
   - What else to ask for if salary is fixed (bonus, equity, PTO, remote, title)

6. Closing Script
   - How to end the conversation
   - Follow-up email template

#tone
Confident but collaborative. Assertive without being aggressive.</span><code style="white-space: pre-wrap;font-size: 16px;line-height: 20px;font-weight: 500;">
</code></code></pre><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: none;"></div><h3 class="header-anchor-post" style="position: relative;font-family: 'SF Pro Display',-apple-system-headline,system-ui,-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,'Segoe UI',Roboto,Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif,'Apple Color Emoji','Segoe UI Emoji','Segoe UI Symbol';font-weight: bold;-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;-moz-osx-font-smoothing: antialiased;-webkit-appearance: optimizelegibility;-moz-appearance: optimizelegibility;appearance: optimizelegibility;margin: 1em 0 0.625em 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 1.16em;font-size: 1.375em;"><strong>🚨 Need help with AI?
